status.full_text: @MaritvanDijk77 @jetbrains Wow! Amazing news! I know very few people like you that can explain software like you do, so this sounds like a fantastic match! https://t.co/vaHCwFrc6c

Did #Azure run out of servers?!

"Sorry, we are currently experiencing high demand in North Europe region, and cannot fulfill your request at this time. [...] please follow this link https://t.co/iT6pgwnGeF for more details on how to create a region access request."
We are seeing this for a few days now.
@Argorak @timClicks Totally makes sense. You first have to prove viability internally with existing people and projects before commiting new budgets to it.
@Niklas_L This is the responsibility of multiple people, team leads, group directors and even comitees.
@Niklas_L I'd say yes, given that I have a lot of colleagues who stay with my employer for decades: https://t.co/skmEkWnpW3

@Niklas_L It has some downsides, too, but it better integrates the task with the technical requirements of the individual roles, so I think this achieves overall better aligment with company goals but also individual skills and capacities of teams.

It makes me sad to see that a standards commitees in our industry looks like this. So many fundamental decisions that affect the global population for years to come are made in men-only meetings. How many standardization bodies ensure diversity beyond member org represenation? https://t.co/niSdqqCK66
@ezagroba Literally. :/
Oh, I wasn't aware that there is a self-hosted version of @getsentry: https://t.co/fFahtsveLM
@beriberikix That's my main point. Usually these comitees do not consider this an issue. So its on us, if we are part of such a group, to point it out.

@sebs303 @gazebo_c I wouldn't call failure to recognise lack of diversity as an issue sexism. It's like with most manels: individually the men didn't do anything wrong, but combining their decisions turns it into a problem.

Reading especially this chapters shows that this book is from a pre-Node.js time. The content is great, but readers have to deal with Java code and XML notation, which is definitely not MY preferred technology. #restinpractice https://t.co/CqtwI94s3O

On a few occasions I tried to add a semantic layer to the messages exchanged between systems, but today the solution that offers the most value for me is adding JSON schemas to everything, which serves both as a documentation AND as a way to validate messages. #RestInPractice https://t.co/g5WYHFcNv4
@gazebo_c What do you want to do? @code is very nice, and since it's built using web technologies it runs on your computer but also in the browser.

@m4nl5r Yes, thrift (https://t.co/uYbhn1byci) looks great, because it standardizes a solution for this problem and allows temas to use the same source for the schema definition.

Reminds me of protobuf but with RPC.

REST in Practice - a reading guide: https://t.co/bTaKJvNLRL

The book was published in 2010 and some of its contents have not aged well, it still offers a lot to learn. In this post I will give my recommendations on which sections are a must read, and which ones can be skipped.

I am teaching #TDD these days and noticed that there is one step that is not too obvious but helps to keep focus on what what to implement: using higher level functions to express logic instead of diving directly into the nitty gritty implementation detail. >

Once you have the structure of your implementation, you can implement isMember and addMember.

This way you are not distracted by figuring out how to do it before having a good understanding of what to do.
@Niklas_L Yes, I then say that if they make it public it's a new liability, which makes it harder to change in the future.
5 years ago today, we put our household on a moving truck to #Trondheim. Would do it again! https://t.co/1AJ7g7DRIN
@TheaClay https://t.co/5tIP3bjPir
@Churchkey90 Ist aus dem Archiv üôä
@Niklas_L In my book is still TDD because we only focus on this one feature. In JavaScript we then often use closures which are internal anyway, so it's more work to make them public.
@Niklas_L @Morl99 Yes, very good point. I do the same.

@Rene_Wiersma I don't see how TDD has an influence on the internal implementation (and it shouldn't). My point here was that it's clearer to first write in high level functions vs. diving into the implementation detail right away.

@Rene_Wiersma listOfMembers.contains(member) 

would work, but here you already need to know that listOfMembers
- exists
- is a list that has the contains() API

Two more things that are easy for experienced developers, but not straightforward for beginners.
@chrmaske Well, there is a good reason why this Tweet was sent from the south coast of Norway üòâ
@Rene_Wiersma Yes, but the point is to reduce cognitive load already at the beginning. The first test does not cause these functions to emerge, but they are already very useful at this stage.
@Rene_Wiersma Ok, noted.

git push

every 5 minutes, but yes. https://t.co/4Eq6245kWt

Surprise! My bank (Sparebank 1 Markets AS) just closed the online access to my stock account, because of technical reasons. It only works for Norwegian citizens. I still can call them to trade, but WTF? https://t.co/pWnQ6qW7uI

Not uncommon for Seniors. It's not a big issue IMHO: if you want to leave then they either offer you a termination agreement (who wants people on payroll that have no interest in working for the company any more?). If not, you have a relaxed half year documenting your stuff. https://t.co/yuHJsnuz5O

My junior is happy that they are learning basics in project management (how to prioritize), architecture (how to divide software problems in small modules) and testing (write tests first to create clarity). That kind of feedback makes me happy.

I had the absolute pleasure to attend a @microbit_edu workshop at Our Lady's & Tarach Secondary School in #Kenya with @i_amthecode where young girls are learning to code! I said a few words about that learning to program teaches you a skill that allows you to work from anywhere! https://t.co/FOoWDQEIkz

We as a software industry really need to aim for inclusion and must put in the effort to make our communities open and welcoming to people from all around the globe, because they bring the knowledge about local problems and will solve them where it has a direct impact.
It's really fantastic to know that @NordicTweets supports this effort through supporting the micro:bit foundation: https://t.co/V7rfM32bjE
I have seen Einar's workshops and he is a great teacher! https://t.co/LrVzcMeHbU

Some great insight today from my junior re teaching programming: @code LiveShare is brilliant, because they can explore the entire codebase of the project, while following me. This allows them to quickly look up things they might not have in memory. >

That does not work when I share my screen, or when I gather them around to watch my screen when we are in the same room. Then they see only what I think is important for me at the moment.

So in the future I will use LiveShare always, even if we are in the same room.

Note that when you are using an email forwarder, some forwarded emails will be lost because the sender's domain does not allow forwarding in their #DMARC policy. This needs to be fixed in your forwarding MX implementation.

Good question in a brain picking üç¥üß† call today: how do you stay engaged when there are constantly new things to learn and you don't really know, which ones will be relevant in a few years?

There is a saying that if you do what you enjoy, you will find the job for these skills. https://t.co/NoTvPAnYh0

This has been true for me. I also made decisions to not to learn highly marketable skills (e.g. Java, Crypto) because they didn't appeal to me, and also switched to less marketable skills at the time (from serverbased PHP to serverless JavaScript), because I was seeing potential.

I then also found the projects to test out these skills, which helped me to learn them more effectively. I've talked about one of the tricks I use to try out new things safely here: https://t.co/ukqiTxzJ9o

@Ocramius @NordicTweets It's a bit tricky to make this work good, you need to only notify on significant position changes. GNSS is not super precise and changes a few meters between fixes. So you need some backend logic to filter out "noise".

@maaretp What is "that"?

@maaretp I think the way to have expensive people involved in a small project is to treat them as consultants. I'd pull them in the concept phase and then to pull them in once  in a while to review important changes / milestones / deliverables.

@maaretp I don't think there is a good answer if you are an employee and not a solo-freelancer, you are supposed to work with others, and you create value by multiplying your skills with others. And organizations are successfull because of this sum-of-all-is-bigger-than-individual-parts.

One key number for a businesses is revenue per employee, and you can look at these numbers to get an understanding if your business is doing good (compared to the industry peers), and then assests how salaries are compared to this number, and the growth strategy.
